title: Coping with Hearing Challenges at Work
chief_complaint: I am very concerned about the impact my hearing loss is having on my work performance. My immediate supervisor has questioned my ability to cope with the listening challenges of my new position.

problem_summary.course: Chronic; has worn hearing aids for 6 years. Current aids fitted 1 year ago.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Difficulty hearing in groups and noise; work-related stress and fatigue.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Significant difficulty at work (meetings, minute taking); reports feeling worn out; has taken 10 sick days in the last year due to work-related stress.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Highly motivated (Importance 10/10) to improve hearing to maintain employment.

history.present_illness: Patient works as an administrative assistant (35 hrs/week). She has been with the employer 25 years but in a new position for 1 year. She reports her current hearing aids are not meeting her needs at work, specifically in meetings and noisy situations.
history.otologic_history: No history of tinnitus, dizziness, vertigo, or ear infections.
history.noise_exposure_history: Reports 'much' perceived environmental noise at workplace.
history.medical_psych_history: No other medical concerns; no medications.
history.prior_management: Has worn bilateral HAs for 6 years. Current BTEs with custom molds purchased 1 year ago. Uses an amplified telephone.
history.patient_goals: To improve ability to follow conversation in monthly department meetings (20 people) and committee meetings (5 people) for minute taking.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral symmetrical mild to severe sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), gradually sloping.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs in good agreement with PTAs. WRS indicates slight difficulty recognizing speech.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal middle ear function bilaterally (Type A).

tests.name: Real Ear Measures (REM)
tests.key_findings: Current hearing aids meet DSL v5.0 adult targets for soft (55), average (65), and loud (75) inputs.

tests.name: Amsterdam Checklist for Hearing and Work
tests.key_findings: Revealed high job demand, low job control, high support. 10 sick days taken in past year due to work stress. Workplace has 'much' noise and 'a little' reverberation.

tests.name: COSI (Client Oriented Scale of Improvement)
tests.key_findings: Identified two priority situations: 1. Monthly department meetings (20 people, horseshoe seating). 2. Committee meetings (5 people, boardroom table).

tests.name: Ottawa Personal Decision Guide
tests.key_findings: Compared 3 options: HAs alone, HAs + Table Mic, HAs + Pass-around Mic. Patient chose Option 2 (Table Mic).

tests.name: Ida Line Tool
tests.key_findings: Assessed importance of improving hearing and belief in ability to use specific solutions.

history.present_illness: Patient returned to assess outcomes after using the tabletop conference microphone with her hearing aids for 3 months.
history.prior_management: Implemented Option 2 (hearing aids + tabletop conference microphone) for 3 months.

tests.name: COSI (Client Oriented Scale of Improvement)
tests.key_findings: Degree of change rated as 'better'. Final ability to hear rated as 'most of the time' for identified situations.

tests.name: IOI-AI (International Outcome Inventory for Alternative Interventions)
tests.key_findings: Patient reported high usage and satisfaction, with improved quality of life.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral, symmetrical, mild-to-severe sloping sensorineural hearing loss with good speech recognition ability at elevated levels. While her current amplification meets prescriptive targets, she experiences significant functional deficits in complex work environments involving noise and groups. Self-report measures indicate high levels of work-related stress and fatigue directly linked to auditory effort.
counseling_points: Your hearing aids are working well for one-on-one situations, but meeting rooms present distance and noise challenges that hearing aids alone cannot fully overcome.
An Assistive Listening Device (ALD), such as a table microphone, can bridge the distance between you and the speakers in your meetings.
It is important to manage the stress and fatigue you are feeling; using the ALD should reduce the listening effort required during your workday.
We will implement the table microphone trial and monitor how it affects your ability to take minutes and follow conversations.
notes_for_actor: You are professional but visibly tired and anxious about your job security.
You have taken sick days specifically because the stress of trying to hear at work is exhausting you.
You are open to technology but worried about drawing attention to yourself (hence rejecting the pass-around microphone).
You feel supported by your colleagues but overwhelmed by the demands of the new position.
